modules.title: MODULE 03
modules.description: Simple Sentence Structures and Basic Grammar

topics.title: Predicate Frames, Expression Rules and Complex Sentences

practiceQuestions.question: What is the primary function of predicate frames in advanced Dholuo grammar?
options: To determine the phonetic structure of words
To specify the permissible structure of sentences, including argument roles
To replace adverbial expressions with more concise phrases
To define the morphological rules for verb conjugation
practiceQuestions.explanation: Predicate frames in Dholuo grammar specify the permissible structure of sentences, especially focusing on the roles and arrangement of arguments.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following best describes an intransitive predicate frame in Dholuo?
options: A verb that requires both a direct and an indirect object
A verb that takes only one argument, typically a subject
A verb that cannot take any arguments
A verb that must be modified by an adverbial satellite
practiceQuestions.explanation: An intransitive predicate frame involves a verb that takes only one argument, usually the subject.

practiceQuestions.question: In the sentence 'Omondi miyo nyar gi pesa', which argument functions as the direct object?
options: Omondi
nyar gi
pesa
miyo
practiceQuestions.explanation: In this ditransitive sentence, 'pesa' (money) functions as the direct object.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following statements about satellites in Dholuo is true?
options: Satellites are mandatory in every predicate frame
Satellites add additional information to the state of affairs without defining it
Satellites can only be used to indicate time and location
Satellites replace nuclear arguments in a predicate frame
practiceQuestions.explanation: Satellites in Dholuo provide additional information such as time, location, or manner but do not define the core state of affairs.

practiceQuestions.question: In the sentence 'Otieno dhi nam', what is the semantic function of 'nam'?
options: Agent
Goal
Theme
Instrument
practiceQuestions.explanation: 'Nam' (lake) functions as a Goal, indicating the destination of the action.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the key difference between a nuclear predication and an extended predication in Dholuo?
options: Nuclear predication contains only essential arguments, while extended predication includes satellites
Nuclear predication has no verbs, while extended predication always includes an action verb
Extended predication is only used in informal speech, while nuclear predication is formal
Extended predication is a simpler form of nuclear predication with fewer arguments
practiceQuestions.explanation: Nuclear predication consists of the verb and its essential arguments, while extended predication adds satellites for additional detail.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following sentences contains a satellite with the semantic function of time?
options: Juma tang’o ne nyathi buk
Achola kelo pi sani
Jathum miel mamit
Otieno dhi nam
practiceQuestions.explanation: 'Sani' (now) in the sentence 'Achola kelo pi sani' indicates time, functioning as a temporal satellite.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following verbs is most likely to form a ditransitive predicate frame in Dholuo?
options: tho ('to die')
wuok ('to leave')
miyo ('to give')
nindo ('to sleep')
practiceQuestions.explanation: 'Miyo' (to give) typically takes three arguments—subject, indirect object, and direct object—making it a ditransitive verb.

practiceQuestions.question: What type of semantic role does the subject play in the sentence 'Jathum miel mamit'?
options: Patient
Experiencer
Agent
Theme
practiceQuestions.explanation: In the sentence 'Jathum miel mamit' (The musician is beautifully singing), the subject 'Jathum' performs the action, making it the Agent.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the correct structure of a monotransitive predicate frame in Dholuo?
options: (NP) + V
(NP) + V + (NP)
(NP) + V + (NP) + (NP)
(NP) + (NP) + V
practiceQuestions.explanation: A monotransitive predicate frame involves a verb with two arguments: a subject and a direct object, structured as (NP) + V + (NP).

practiceQuestions.question: In Functional Grammar (FG), what is the purpose of the Subj function?
options: To indicate tense and aspect in a sentence
To mark the entity from which the perspective of the predication is determined
To always occupy the preverbal position in all languages
To determine the number of arguments a verb can take
practiceQuestions.explanation: The Subj function marks the entity from whose perspective the predication is interpreted.

practiceQuestions.question: Why is the Obj function assigned in Functional Grammar?
options: To introduce an additional verb in a sentence
To mark the main subject of a passive construction
To function as the second point of departure or vantage point
To replace an alpha function in predication
practiceQuestions.explanation: In FG, the Obj function is used to indicate the second point of departure or vantage point within the sentence structure.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following best explains why Subj assignment is not necessary in Dholuo grammar?
options: The language does not have active-passive transformations
The order of constituents can only be explained using semantic and pragmatic functions
There are no distinct subject-object markers in Dholuo
The verbal predicate always comes before all other terms
practiceQuestions.explanation: Subj assignment is not necessary in Dholuo grammar because constituent order is best explained using semantic and pragmatic rather than syntactic functions.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following is TRUE regarding constituent order in Dholuo?
options: The preverbal position 1 must always be occupied
Verbal predicates must always appear in post-verbal positions
The post-verbal position 2 is always occupied by the object
All non-alpha terms must appear before the verb
practiceQuestions.explanation: In Dholuo, preverbal position 1 is consistently occupied, often by an alpha function like the Agent.

practiceQuestions.question: In which of the following Dholuo sentences is position 2 occupied by a Goal function?
options: "Otieno nindo"
"Otieno ochamo rech"
"Otieno miyo paka chak"
"Otieno ong'iewo nanga ne nyathine"
practiceQuestions.explanation: In the sentence 'Otieno miyo paka chak', 'chak' functions as a Goal in position 2.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following terms is NOT classified as an alpha function?
options: Agent
Goal
Jatedo
Otieno
practiceQuestions.explanation: In Functional Grammar, Goal is not considered an alpha function; it is a satellite or non-core semantic role.

practiceQuestions.question: According to the study, which of the following sentences follows the standard constituent order in Dholuo?
options: "Otieno ong'iewo ne nyathine nanga"
"Otieno rech ochamo"
"Paka Otieno miyo chak"
"Otieno ong'iewo nanga"
practiceQuestions.explanation: The sentence 'Otieno ong'iewo ne nyathine nanga' follows the standard constituent order with alpha and non-alpha terms placed according to their semantic function.

practiceQuestions.question: What determines the position of non-alpha terms in a Dholuo sentence?
options: The complexity of the verb
Their hierarchical order relative to Ben function
The presence of multiple verbal predicates
The number of alpha terms in the sentence
practiceQuestions.explanation: The position of non-alpha terms in Dholuo is determined by their semantic-pragmatic hierarchy relative to the Ben function.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following observations about Dholuo constituent order is INCORRECT?
options: An alpha term must always occupy the preverbal position
Non-alpha terms lower than Ben on the SFH cannot occupy position 2 if a higher-ranked term is present
The Obj function is crucial for understanding active-passive relationships
Semantic and pragmatic functions explain word order better than syntactic functions
practiceQuestions.explanation: The Obj function is not crucial for explaining active-passive relationships in Dholuo; such structures are better explained by semantic and pragmatic roles.

practiceQuestions.question: Why is the notion of 'syntactic function' irrelevant to the description of Dholuo?
options: Dholuo does not have subject-object agreement
Dholuo grammar is best explained through semantic functions rather than fixed syntactic roles
Functional Grammar does not apply to African languages
Dholuo lacks a clear distinction between verbs and nouns
practiceQuestions.explanation: In Dholuo, syntactic functions are not primary; semantic and pragmatic roles offer a better explanation for grammatical structure.

practiceQuestions.question: According to Functional Grammar, what is the role of a Theme in a sentence?
options: To introduce a predication by specifying the universe of discourse
To conclude a statement with additional information
To emphasize the verb of the predication
To replace the subject of the sentence
practiceQuestions.explanation: The Theme sets up the context by introducing the universe of discourse for the predication.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following Dholuo utterances contains a Theme function?
options: "Ohero koko, en"
"Macha e japuonj, ma wiye oyugno cha"
"Nyako ma biro no en osiepni?"
"Ok adware, wiiye duong' no"
practiceQuestions.explanation: The utterance 'Nyako ma biro no en osiepni?' introduces the theme before the predication.

practiceQuestions.question: In the example "Joluo, gin gikia ohala," what function does "Joluo" serve?
options: Alpha term
Tail
Verb phrase
Theme
practiceQuestions.explanation: "Joluo" introduces the discourse, functioning as the Theme.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following best describes the function of a Tail in Dholuo grammar?
options: It modifies the verb to indicate tense and aspect
It is an afterthought that provides additional information to a completed predication
It must always follow a Theme in a sentence
It replaces the subject to avoid repetition
practiceQuestions.explanation: The Tail provides additional or clarifying information after the main predication.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following statements about Theme and Tail functions in Dholuo is TRUE?
options: A sentence can contain both a Theme and a Tail
A Tail must always appear before the predication
A Theme and a Tail must appear in the same sentence
A Tail must always be preceded by a pause
practiceQuestions.explanation: It is possible for a Dholuo sentence to include both a Theme and a Tail.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following sentences contains a Tail function?
options: "Wan, wan jo mohero somo"
"Oloo, en oonge gi weche mathoth"
"Oonge paro, jakong’o no"
"Nyako ma biro no en osiepni?"
practiceQuestions.explanation: The phrase 'jakong’o no' functions as a Tail, providing additional detail.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the primary difference between a Theme and a Tail in Dholuo?
options: A Theme introduces the discourse, while a Tail adds information after the predication
A Theme follows the verb, while a Tail precedes the verb
A Theme can appear anywhere in a sentence, while a Tail is always at the beginning
A Tail only occurs in interrogative sentences, while a Theme occurs in declarative ones
practiceQuestions.explanation: A Theme introduces the sentence's context; a Tail follows and adds to the predication.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following sentences demonstrates the use of a Tail that requires a pause?
options: "Ohero koko, en"
"Macha e japuonj, ma wiye oyugno cha"
"In, in jakuo"
"Kik isud buta, in"
practiceQuestions.explanation: The clause 'ma wiye oyugno cha' is an inserted Tail after a pause, giving extra detail.

practiceQuestions.question: What does the sentence "Macha, ma wiye oyugno cha, e japuonj" demonstrate about Tail function?
options: A Tail can be inserted parenthetically within a predication
A Tail must always be positioned at the end of a sentence
A Theme must follow a Tail in all cases
A Tail is always introduced with a conjunction
practiceQuestions.explanation: The Tail 'ma wiye oyugno cha' is inserted parenthetically, demonstrating its flexible position.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following best explains the role of the demonstrative pronoun in the sentence "Mano e maber, ma ok miya tich matek"?
options: It introduces the Theme of the sentence
It acts as the Tail, providing additional information about the subject
It replaces the verb to indicate the passive voice
It serves as the direct object of the sentence
practiceQuestions.explanation: The demonstrative phrase 'ma ok miya tich matek' acts as a Tail providing further detail.

practiceQuestions.question: According to Functional Grammar theory, which of the following best describes the Topic function?
options: The constituent that introduces new entities into discourse
The constituent that carries the primary stress in a sentence
The constituent about which the predication provides information in a given setting
The constituent that always appears at the end of a sentence
practiceQuestions.explanation: The Topic identifies what the predication is about in the discourse context.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the three characteristics of the Topic function in Functional Grammar?
options: It designates the entity about which something is predicated
It must always be a noun phrase in sentence-initial position
It is often coreferential with a constituent in a preceding or implied question
Any term in a predication can function as a Topic given the right pragmatic conditions
practiceQuestions.explanation: While Topics often occur early, they are not strictly limited to sentence-initial noun phrases.

practiceQuestions.question: In Dholuo, where is the special position for Topic constituents?
options: Postverbal position
Preverbal position
Final position in the clause
Anywhere in the sentence
practiceQuestions.explanation: Dholuo assigns Topic elements to the preverbal position for emphasis or focus.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following statements best differentiates the communicative functions of the sentences "Inego kwach" and "Kwach inego"?
options: The first states what is happening, while the second emphasizes what is happening to the leopard
The first expresses doubt, while the second expresses certainty
The first is used in informal speech, while the second is used in formal contexts
The first is grammatically incorrect, while the second is the only valid structure
practiceQuestions.explanation: Word order reflects focus: 'Kwach inego' places emphasis on the object (leopard).

practiceQuestions.question: Why is "Kwach inego" NOT an appropriate response to the question "Ango ma timore?" ('What is happening here?')?
options: It lacks a verb, making it ungrammatical
It does not explicitly mention the agent of the action
It does not provide general information about what is happening
It uses a verb form that is inappropriate for this type of question
practiceQuestions.explanation: The sentence emphasizes a specific object, not the broader event occurring.

practiceQuestions.question: In response to the question "Itimo kwach nade?" ('What is being done to the leopard?'), which of the following is an appropriate answer?
options: kwach tho
Ineg-e
Nyithindo nego kwach
Kwach inego
practiceQuestions.explanation: "Ineg-e" appropriately aligns with the passive structure asked in the question.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following best represents the general syntactic pattern for Topic marking in Dholuo?
options: Alpha Verb Topic X
Verb Alpha Topic X
Topic Alpha Verb X
Verb Topic Alpha X
practiceQuestions.explanation: Dholuo typically positions the Topic before the Alpha and Verb.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the significance of sentence (g) "Kwach nyithindo nego" compared to (f) "Nyithindo nego kwach"?
options: (g) maintains the default sentence order while (f) marks Focus
(g) assigns Topic function to "kwach," making it the primary referent
(f) is incorrect because "kwach" must always come first
(g) removes the agent of the action, making it ambiguous
practiceQuestions.explanation: In sentence (g), 'kwach' is placed at the front to serve as the Topic.

practiceQuestions.question: In Dholuo, when a Topic element is assigned in a sentence, how does this affect the alpha term?
options: The alpha term remains in its original position
The alpha term must be moved to the postverbal position
The alpha term must still appear in the preverbal position
The alpha term is deleted from the sentence
practiceQuestions.explanation: The alpha term retains its preverbal position even when a Topic is added.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following statements correctly summarizes the relationship between Topic and sentence structure in Dholuo?
options: Topic assignment always requires a change in word order
Topic elements must always appear at the end of a sentence
Topic assignment does not affect sentence structure in any way
Topic marking is optional and does not follow any specific pattern
practiceQuestions.explanation: Assigning a Topic typically results in fronting or reordering sentence elements for clarity.

practiceQuestions.question: According to the study, what is the primary function of the Focus marker [e] in Dholuo?
options: To indicate past tense in declarative sentences
To mark the most salient piece of information in a given pragmatic condition
To serve as a plural marker in noun phrases
To indicate negation in Focus constructions
practiceQuestions.explanation: [e] highlights the most important or emphasized information in the clause.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following statements best describes the distinction between sentence (a) “Otieno e wuoyi” and sentence (b) “Otieno wuoyi”?
options: (a) provides emphasis while (b) introduces contrast
(a) asserts that Otieno is uniquely identified as "the boy," while (b) simply states that he is male
(a) is grammatically incorrect, while (b) is the standard form
(a) introduces a negation while (b) provides an affirmative statement
practiceQuestions.explanation: The presence of [e] in (a) introduces a Focus construction implying uniqueness.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the main factor common to all six 'etics' of Focus identified in the study?
options: They all involve a shift in word order
They all rely on tonal variation for proper interpretation
They all assign informational weight to specific elements in a sentence
They all require explicit marking through Focus particles
practiceQuestions.explanation: All Focus types relate to the communicative emphasis placed on specific parts of the sentence.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following best describes the function of [ma] in Dholuo Focus constructions?
options: It acts as a relativizer but can also contribute to Focus marking
It replaces [e] in all Focus constructions
It only appears in past-tense questions
It serves as a conjunction linking two Focus elements
practiceQuestions.explanation: [ma] acts as a relativizer but also contributes to marking Focus, especially in certain clause types.

practiceQuestions.question: In which of the following contexts is [ma] used as the sole Focus marker instead of [e]?
options: When Focus is applied to noun phrases
When the Focused term appears in a question-word construction
When emphasis is placed on verb conjugation
When indicating negation in relative clauses
practiceQuestions.explanation: [ma] is typically used alone in contexts involving question-word constructions.

practiceQuestions.question: Why is the phrase “Chunya e ma rach” significant in understanding the role of Focus markers in Dholuo?
options: It illustrates a Focus construction where [ma] supports [e] without an identifiable omitted head noun
It demonstrates that [ma] is exclusively used for emotional expressions
It provides an example where [e] alone serves as the Focus marker
It shows that [e] and [ma] must always appear together in Focus constructions
practiceQuestions.explanation: The phrase demonstrates a Focus construction with no overt head noun, where [ma] functions alongside [e].

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following Focus types involves removing incorrect information and replacing it with the correct one?
options: Expanding Focus
Replacing Focus
Restricting Focus
Parallel Focus
practiceQuestions.explanation: Replacing Focus contrasts two elements and corrects a mistaken assumption or alternative.

practiceQuestions.question: How does the phrase “Otieno e ng’at ma nyalo konyowa” illustrate the interaction of [e] and [ma]?
options: It shows that [ma] is redundant in Focus constructions
It demonstrates that [e] and [ma] can co-occur in a Focused relative clause
It reveals that [e] and [ma] have distinct but interchangeable functions
It indicates that Focus marking is optional in such sentences
practiceQuestions.explanation: This sentence shows a valid co-occurrence of [e] and [ma] in a Focused relative clause.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following best summarizes the difference between Completive Focus and Selective Focus?
options: Completive Focus provides entirely new information, whereas Selective Focus highlights an option among known possibilities
Selective Focus always involves negation, whereas Completive Focus does not
Completive Focus applies to pronouns, while Selective Focus applies to nouns
Selective Focus is always marked by [e], whereas Completive Focus requires [ma]
practiceQuestions.explanation: Completive Focus introduces entirely new material, while Selective Focus chooses from given options.

practiceQuestions.question: Based on the study, what is the current assumption regarding Focus marking in Dholuo?
options: Focus is marked inconsistently and cannot be analyzed systematically
The primary Focus markers are [e], [ma], or their combination, but further research is needed to clarify their distribution
Only [ma] functions as a true Focus marker, while [e] is used for emphasis
Focus constructions always require the presence of both [e] and [ma]
practiceQuestions.explanation: The study notes that [e], [ma], or both are used for Focus, though their exact rules need more clarification.

practiceQuestions.question: According to the expression rules in FG, which linguistic feature is not explicitly accounted for?
options: The form of terms, including cases and adpositions
The structure of syllables in Dholuo
The order of elements in a sentence
The use of stress and intonation
practiceQuestions.explanation: Expression rules in FG focus on syntactic and morphological elements, not phonological ones like syllable structure.

practiceQuestions.question: What happens to the verb form in a Dholuo sentence when an incomplete predication occurs?
options: It takes a passive form
It remains unchanged
It moves to the end of the sentence
It takes an auxiliary verb
practiceQuestions.explanation: Incomplete predication results in the passive form of the verb being used.

practiceQuestions.question: In the sentence "oneg diel", what grammatical feature is being demonstrated?
options: Active voice
The use of an auxiliary verb
Passive voice
The preverbal positioning of terms
practiceQuestions.explanation: The verb 'oneg' shows a passive construction with 'diel' (goat) as the subject.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the main factor determining whether a passive or active verb form is used in Dholuo?
options: The presence of a pragmatic function
The structure of the sentence
Whether the predication has an alpha term
The use of prepositions
practiceQuestions.explanation: An alpha term (the primary participant) in predication determines verb voice selection.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following correctly illustrates an active verb form?
options: Oneg diel
Ng'ato nego diel
Wendo wanego-ne diel
Yo sikul ema Atieno
practiceQuestions.explanation: 'Ng'ato nego diel' uses an active verb ('nego') with an explicit subject and object.

practiceQuestions.question: If a term is placed in the preverbal position due to a pragmatic function, what happens to the verbal predicate?
options: The verb takes a passive form
The verb gains an affix marking the prepositional SF of the term
The verb changes to an imperative form
The verb remains unchanged
practiceQuestions.explanation: Preverbal pragmatic terms affect the verb by causing it to incorporate affixes indicating the semantic function.

practiceQuestions.question: In the sentence "Wendo wanego-ne diel", which grammatical function causes the change in the verb form?
options: The use of an auxiliary verb
The presence of a pragmatic function
The use of an object pronoun
The omission of the subject
practiceQuestions.explanation: The pragmatic function of the preverbal element 'Wendo' triggers a verb modification.

practiceQuestions.question: Why do some semantic functions (SFs), such as Goal, have zero prepositional marking?
options: To simplify the grammar rules
To avoid inconsistencies in the general expression rules
Because Dholuo does not allow prepositions
Because they do not affect the sentence meaning
practiceQuestions.explanation: Zero marking ensures consistency in how semantic functions are expressed across different contexts.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the purpose of expression rules in FG?
options: To dictate the exact translation of words
To determine the surface realization of linguistic elements
To create new vocabulary in Dholuo
To define the phonetic structure of words
practiceQuestions.explanation: Expression rules help specify how abstract functions and roles are realized in actual speech or writing.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following is not a function of expression rules in Functional Grammar?
options: Determining stress and intonation
Regulating word order
Defining predicate realization
Assigning grammatical cases to words
practiceQuestions.explanation: FG expression rules deal more with syntactic realization than with assigning grammatical cases explicitly.

practiceQuestions.question: According to the study, which of the following semantic functions (SFs) do not require prepositional marking?
options: Possession and Direction
Goal and Beneficiary
Ø, PO, Fo, Proc, and Dir (without content-word preposition)
Locative and Source
practiceQuestions.explanation: These SFs are expressed without prepositions, often through position or verb morphology.

practiceQuestions.question: When expressing Possession (Poss) for a singular possessed element in Dholuo, which preposition is used?
options: gi
mag
mar
ne
practiceQuestions.explanation: ‘mar’ is used for singular possessed elements to indicate possession.

practiceQuestions.question: In Dholuo, what is the correct prepositional marking for Companion (Comp) and Instruction (Instr) functions?
options: ne
gi
e
yo
practiceQuestions.explanation: ‘gi’ is the appropriate preposition to express Companion and Instruction roles.

practiceQuestions.question: How is Focus function morphologically expressed in a Dholuo sentence?
options: By adding [e(ma)] immediately after the focused term
By placing the term at the end of the sentence
By using a different verb tense
By omitting the subject in the sentence
practiceQuestions.explanation: Focus is marked morphologically by the postposed particle [e] or [ema].

practiceQuestions.question: In which case does the general preposition "e" appear in a predication?
options: When marking a term assigned the Beneficiary function
When a term takes a prepositional content-word marker like "yo"
When the term has zero semantic function
When the term is assigned a Focus function
practiceQuestions.explanation: ‘e’ appears with prepositions like ‘yo’ in directional expressions.

practiceQuestions.question: Which preposition is used when marking the Beneficiary (Ben) and Recipient (Rec) functions?
options: mar
gi
ne
e
practiceQuestions.explanation: ‘ne’ is the preposition used for both Beneficiary and Recipient functions.

practiceQuestions.question: What happens if a prepositionally marked term is assigned the Topic function in Dholuo?
options: The preposition is removed
The term moves to the preverbal position, causing morphological changes in the verb
The term remains in its original place but gains an extra suffix
There is no morphological effect
practiceQuestions.explanation: Topicalized terms move to the front, affecting the verb through agreement or inflection.

practiceQuestions.question: Which sentence correctly represents Direction (Dir) with a content-word preposition?
options: Atieno odhi e yo sikul
Atieno odhi yo sikul
Sikul odhi Atieno
Yo sikul ema Atieno odhi ne
practiceQuestions.explanation: ‘yo sikul’ is the appropriate directional phrase without the general preposition 'e'.

practiceQuestions.question: When a plural possessed element is involved in a possession statement, which preposition is used?
options: mar
gi
mag
ne
practiceQuestions.explanation: ‘mag’ indicates plural possession in Dholuo.

practiceQuestions.question: In which case does a term assigned the Focus function appear as "... Xl e(ma) ..." in a sentence?
options: When it is the object of the sentence
When it appears in the postverbal position
When it moves to the preverbal position
When it is not prepositionally marked
practiceQuestions.explanation: When the focused term is preverbal, it appears with the marker [e] or [ema] following it.

practiceQuestions.question: According to Functional Grammar, how are the predications underlying linguistic expressions initially structured?
options: They follow a strict word order from the start.
They are unordered and require rules to establish linear order.
They always begin with a verb.
They are structured based on English grammar principles.
practiceQuestions.explanation: Predications start as unordered structures and require expression rules to define word order.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the primary role of expression rules in Functional Grammar?
options: To add more words to sentences.
To determine the meaning of words in isolation.
To establish the linear order of constituents in a sentence.
To remove unnecessary words from a sentence.
practiceQuestions.explanation: Expression rules define how elements are ordered linearly in a sentence.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the preferential tendencies in constituent ordering?
options: Placing constituents with the same function in the same structural position.
Assigning special positions to certain categories of constituents.
Avoiding complex sentence structures entirely.
Ordering constituents from left to right based on increasing complexity.
practiceQuestions.explanation: Avoiding complex structures is not a tendency in Functional Grammar.

practiceQuestions.question: In Dholuo, what determines the placement of constituents within functional patterns?
options: Syntactic functions
Semantic functions
Prepositions
Random selection
practiceQuestions.explanation: Semantic functions guide the linear ordering of constituents in Dholuo.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the designated preverbal position for an alpha term in Dholuo?
options: P1
V
A
Ø
practiceQuestions.explanation: Position A (alpha) is reserved for terms with core roles and high discourse prominence.

practiceQuestions.question: Which constituent typically occupies the first postverbal position in Dholuo?
options: The Theme
One of the non-alpha terms (Goal, Recipient, Beneficiary)
The Verb
The Tail
practiceQuestions.explanation: Non-alpha terms often appear in the first postverbal slot after the verb.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following represents a common postverbal structure in Dholuo?
options: V Rec Go
Rec V Go
Go V Rec
Ben Rec V
practiceQuestions.explanation: V Rec Go is a typical postverbal ordering of constituents.

practiceQuestions.question: What distinguishes the (Vø) type of predication in Dholuo?
options: It includes both a Goal and a Locative.
It has no postverbal constituent with a semantic function.
It always ends with a Beneficiary.
It only appears in interrogative sentences.
practiceQuestions.explanation: (Vø) predications consist solely of a verb, lacking postverbal SF-marked constituents.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following examples represents the (V Go Loc) structure?
options: Ng'ato omiyo Atieno pesa mathoth
Jatedo otuono japidi chiemo
Mama oketo kuon e mesa
Ng'at cha paro chiege
practiceQuestions.explanation: This sentence illustrates a verb followed by a Goal and a Locative element.

practiceQuestions.question: In an extended predication, what happens if an X-constituent (e.g., Beneficiary) is placed after the binding constituent?
options: The sentence structure remains correct.
The sentence becomes ungrammatical.
The X-constituent must always appear before the verb.
The meaning of the sentence changes completely.
practiceQuestions.explanation: Extended predications allow for flexible placement of X-constituents post-binding.

topics.title: Predicate Frames, Expression Rules and Complex Sentences

practiceQuestions.question: What is the primary linguistic phenomenon under discussion in the provided study?
options: Subject-Verb Agreement
Word Fronting in Question Formation
Tense and Aspect Marking
Gender Marking in Pronouns
practiceQuestions.explanation: The study focuses on how word fronting operates in forming questions in Dholuo.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following best describes the contrast between straight and Focus interrogatives in Dholuo?
options: Straight interrogatives always have preverbal question words, while Focus interrogatives do not.
Focus interrogatives contain a Focus-marking element [ma], while straight interrogatives do not.
Straight interrogatives are used for rhetorical questions only.
Focus interrogatives occur only in informal speech.
practiceQuestions.explanation: Focus interrogatives use the marker [ma], which is absent in straight interrogatives.

practiceQuestions.question: In the study, which of the following is an example of a Focus interrogative?
options: Jakuo okawo ang'o?
Ere wuon ot?
Ang'o ma jakuo okawo?
Bende oyud jakuo?
practiceQuestions.explanation: This example includes the Focus-marking element [ma], typical of Focus interrogatives.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the role of the Focus-marking element [ma] in Dholuo question formation?
options: It signals past tense in interrogatives.
It marks the presence of an informational gap in a sentence.
It differentiates straight interrogatives from Focus interrogatives.
It serves as a negation marker.
practiceQuestions.explanation: [ma] is a structural marker that distinguishes Focus interrogatives.

practiceQuestions.question: According to the study, which type of interrogative construction in Dholuo is always a 'straight interrogative'?
options: Questions that seek confirmation using words like [bende, donge, koso].
Questions that contain the Focus-marking element [ma].
Questions that have both preverbal and postverbal question words.
Questions that involve an alpha term.
practiceQuestions.explanation: Confirmation questions always follow the straight interrogative pattern in Dholuo.

practiceQuestions.question: What linguistic strategy does the question ‘Ang’o ma jakuo okawo?’ employ?
options: It uses word order inversion.
It employs an optional Q-fronting rule.
It deletes the subject of the sentence.
It relies on subject-verb agreement to form a question.
practiceQuestions.explanation: The question demonstrates the optional fronting of question elements in Focus interrogatives.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following best describes the relationship between declarative and interrogative Focus constructions in Dholuo?
options: Declarative Focus constructions mirror Focus interrogatives in structure, but they serve different communicative functions.
Declarative Focus constructions can only occur in past tense, while interrogative Focus constructions occur in all tenses.
Focus interrogatives do not require a Focus-marking element, while declarative Focus constructions do.
There is no structural relationship between them.
practiceQuestions.explanation: They share structure, but differ in communicative intent—one makes a statement, the other asks.

practiceQuestions.question: What distinguishes Type (ii) interrogatives from Type (iv) interrogatives in the study?
options: Type (ii) interrogatives allow free variation in question-word position, while Type (iv) does not.
Type (ii) interrogatives contain an alpha term, while Type (iv) interrogatives contain a non-alpha term.
Type (ii) interrogatives are rhetorical, while Type (iv) interrogatives seek genuine information.
Type (ii) interrogatives always appear in declarative sentences.
practiceQuestions.explanation: The classification is based on the type of term—alpha for Type (ii), non-alpha for Type (iv).

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following sentences best illustrates a straight interrogative in Dholuo?
options: Ng'a ma sibuor ochamo?
Ang’o ma jakuo okawo?
Donge oyud jakuo?
Ng’a ma chamo punda?
practiceQuestions.explanation: This is a confirmation-type question that falls under straight interrogatives.

practiceQuestions.question: What can be concluded about the distribution of interrogative constructions in Dholuo based on the study?
options: Dholuo only has Focus interrogatives, and straight interrogatives do not exist.
The language allows both Focus and straight interrogatives, with some occurring in free variation and others in complementary distribution.
Word order is completely fixed in all Dholuo interrogative structures.
The presence of the Focus-marking element [ma] is optional in all interrogative structures.
practiceQuestions.explanation: Dholuo utilizes both forms, with flexible distribution patterns depending on context.

practiceQuestions.question: What position is explicitly avoided for the time adverb in Dholuo?
options: Between the subject and verb
At the end of the sentence
Between the verb and object
Before the subject
practiceQuestions.explanation: Dholuo avoids placing time adverbs between the verb and the object.

practiceQuestions.question: In the sentence “Otieno nyalo loso kom kawuono ne min,” what can be said about the positioning of the TA [kawuono]?
options: It is highly marked but acceptable.
It is completely ill-formed.
It is the most natural placement.
It is only acceptable in informal speech.
practiceQuestions.explanation: The placement of the TA here is marked but still within acceptable grammatical bounds.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following sentences is completely ill-formed due to incorrect TA placement?
options: Otieno loso kom kawuono ne min gi spana e skul.
Otieno Ioso kawuono kom ne min gi spana e skul.
Otieno loso kom ne min gi spana kawuono e skul.
Otieno kawuono loso kom ne min gi spana e skul.
practiceQuestions.explanation: Placing the TA between the auxiliary and the verb results in an ill-formed sentence.

practiceQuestions.question: Why is sentence (f) “Otieno nyalo kawuono loso kom ne min” ill-formed?
options: The TA [kawuono] is placed incorrectly between the modal auxiliary and the verb.
The TA is missing a focus marker.
The TA should always be placed at the beginning of the sentence.
The sentence lacks a direct object.
practiceQuestions.explanation: Placing a TA between a modal auxiliary and main verb is ungrammatical in Dholuo.

practiceQuestions.question: What position is the TA [kawuono] occupying in the sentence “Kawuono Otieno nyalo loso kom ne min”?
options: Object position
Focus position
Pre-initial (PI) position
Post-verbal position
practiceQuestions.explanation: The TA is in a pre-initial position before the subject, functioning as a topical element.

practiceQuestions.question: Why is sentence (a) “Otieno loso kom ne min gi spana e skul kawuono” considered highly acceptable?
options: The TA [kawuono] is placed at the beginning, giving it prominence.
All term constituents are in their expected order.
The sentence follows a strict Subject-Object-Verb (SOV) order.
The modal auxiliary governs the placement of the TA.
practiceQuestions.explanation: This sentence is well-formed as it maintains expected word order, including correct placement of the TA.

practiceQuestions.question: In the response to the question “To kawuono?” which sentence structure is most appropriate?
options: Otieno loso kom ne min gi spana e skul kawuono.
Kawuono Otieno loso kom ne min gi spana e skul.
Otieno Ioso kom kawuono ne min gi spana e skul.
Otieno loso kawuono kom ne min gi spana e skul.
practiceQuestions.explanation: Pre-initial placement of the TA reflects topic-comment structure, which is appropriate as a response.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the possible structural explanation for the TA in sentence (e) “Otieno Ioso kom ne min gi spana e skul kawuono”?
options: It occupies a pre-initial (PI) position as a topic marker.
It is a free element without structural commitment.
It is an example of nuclearization.
Any of the above could be correct.
practiceQuestions.explanation: The placement allows for multiple interpretations including nuclearization and topic marking.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following best describes the markedness of sentence (g) “Kawuono Otieno loso kom ne min gi spana e skul”?
options: It is highly marked and unacceptable.
It is highly acceptable due to topic assignment.
It is ill-formed because it lacks a modal auxiliary.
It violates the basic word order of Dholuo.
practiceQuestions.explanation: Though marked, this sentence is acceptable as it uses pre-initial positioning for emphasis.

practiceQuestions.question: Which sentence structure is considered the most marked to be ill but still acceptable?
options: Otieno nyalo loso kom ne min kawuono.
Otieno loso kom kawuono ne min gi spana e skul.
Otieno nyalo loso kawuono kom ne min.
Otieno loso kawuono kom ne min gi spana e skul.
practiceQuestions.explanation: Though unusual, this structure doesn't violate grammatical rules, making it marked but acceptable.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the primary function of a cleft-construction in Dholuo?
options: To introduce a new tense marker in the sentence
To place focus on a specific element in the sentence
To change the meaning of the verb
To replace the subject with an object
practiceQuestions.explanation: Cleft-constructions in Dholuo serve to focus attention on a particular element in the sentence, making it more prominent in discourse.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following is an example of a cleft-construction proper?
options: Gi ma nyathi dwaro en rech
Gi ma japuonj ni timo en (mana) chwado nyithindo
Japuonj no ema jodongo ohero
Nyathi dwaro rech
practiceQuestions.explanation: 'Japuonj no ema jodongo ohero' is a cleft-construction proper because it explicitly places focus on the subject through syntactic restructuring.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the key difference between a cleft-construction and a non-cleft construction?
options: Cleft-constructions separate a unified phrase to emphasize a particular element
Non-cleft constructions require additional markers for focus
Cleft-constructions eliminate the need for a subject
Non-cleft constructions do not allow verbs
practiceQuestions.explanation: Cleft-constructions are used to separate elements in a sentence, allowing specific emphasis on a chosen part, unlike non-cleft constructions.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following sentences is a pseudo-cleft construction?
options: Rech ema nyathi dwaro
Gi ma nyathi dwaro en rech
Japuonj no ema jodongo ohero
Nyathi dwaro rech
practiceQuestions.explanation: 'Gi ma nyathi dwaro en rech' is a pseudo-cleft construction because it focuses on a constituent using a relative clause, without requiring transformation rules.

practiceQuestions.question: In cleft-constructions proper, which part of the sentence usually appears in the preverbal position?
options: The verb
A non-alpha term
A conjunction
The subject pronoun
practiceQuestions.explanation: A cleft-construction proper typically places a non-alpha (non-subject or object) term in the preverbal position to highlight it.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following is a correct transformation of the non-cleft sentence 'Nyathi dwaro rech' into a cleft-construction proper?
options: Rech ema nyathi dwaro
Gi ma nyathi dwaro en rech
Nyathi ema dwaro rech
Nyathi ni dwaro rech
practiceQuestions.explanation: 'Rech ema nyathi dwaro' is a cleft-construction proper that focuses on the object 'rech' through fronting.

practiceQuestions.question: Why do pseudo-cleft constructions not require a movement rule in a transformational grammar (TG) account?
options: Because they are already in their most natural syntactic order
Because they do not involve focus constructions
Because they only require the insertion of lexical elements
Because they change the tense of the verb
practiceQuestions.explanation: Pseudo-cleft constructions do not need movement rules in TG because they only require lexical insertion without syntactic reordering.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following sentences is a non-cleft construction?
options: Rech ema nyathi dwaro
Gi ma japuonj ni timo en (mana) chwado nyithindo
Jodongo obero japuonj no
Japuonj no ema jodongo ohero
practiceQuestions.explanation: 'Jodongo obero japuonj no' is a non-cleft construction because it follows the standard subject-verb-object order without focus restructuring.

practiceQuestions.question: What distinguishes cleft-constructions proper from pseudo-cleft constructions?
options: Cleft-constructions proper require movement of non-alpha terms
Pseudo-cleft constructions require verb inversion
Cleft-constructions proper always follow a subject-verb-object order
Pseudo-cleft constructions are only used in past tense
practiceQuestions.explanation: Cleft-constructions proper involve syntactic movement of a focused element, unlike pseudo-cleft constructions which maintain normal word order.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following best explains why cleft-constructions are considered focus constructions?
options: They emphasize a specific part of the sentence
They eliminate the need for objects
They are always used with past tense verbs
They require multiple subject markers
practiceQuestions.explanation: Cleft-constructions highlight a specific part of the sentence, making it the focal point, which is why they are categorized as focus constructions.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the primary difference between [ere] and [ni kanye]?
options: [Ere] is used only in the past tense, while [ni kanye] is used in the present
[Ere] semantically combines the meanings of [kanye] and [ni], while [ni kanye] does not
[Ni kanye] has no equivalent meaning in Dholuo
[Ere] and [ni kanye] can be used interchangeably without restrictions
practiceQuestions.explanation: [Ere] semantically combines the meanings of [kanye] and [ni], providing a more compact form than [ni kanye].

practiceQuestions.question: Why is the sentence 'Pala ne ere' ill-formed?
options: Because [ere] can only be used in the present tense
Because [ne] must always follow [ere]
Because [ere] is only used with pronouns
Because [ere] must always follow a noun
practiceQuestions.explanation: [Ere] is limited to present tense contexts, so using it with the past tense marker [ne] results in an ill-formed sentence.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following sentences correctly uses [ere]?
options: i-ere
Pala ne ere
Ere-i
Pala kanye ni
practiceQuestions.explanation: 'Ere-i' correctly uses [ere] before a pronoun to form a proper question in Dholuo.

practiceQuestions.question: What is required to form a well-structured question using [ni kanye]?
options: The sentence must be in the past tense
The sentence must follow a strict Subject-Verb-Object order
The sentence must use the locative copula [ni]
The sentence must begin with [ere]
practiceQuestions.explanation: Using [ni kanye] correctly requires the inclusion of the locative copula [ni].

practiceQuestions.question: When forming a question about the location of a pronoun, how should [ere] be positioned?
options: It must always come before the pronoun
It must always come after the pronoun
It must be omitted when a pronoun is used
It must always be used with [ni kanye]
practiceQuestions.explanation: [Ere] precedes the pronoun to correctly form a question about location in Dholuo.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following is a correct sentence using [ni kanye]?
options: Kanye pala.
Pala ni kanye?
Pala kanye ni?
Ere pala kanye?
practiceQuestions.explanation: 'Pala ni kanye?' is the correct structure for asking a location question using [ni kanye].

practiceQuestions.question: Why is the sentence 'i-ere' incorrect?
options: Because [ere] cannot be used with pronouns
Because [ere] must always precede the pronoun
Because [ere] cannot be used in present tense
Because [ere] must always be followed by [ni]
practiceQuestions.explanation: 'i-ere' is incorrect because [ere] must precede the pronoun, making 'ere-i' the correct form.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following statements is true about the use of [ere] in Dholuo?
options: It can be used in past and present tense
It must always follow a noun
It can only occur in the present tense
It is interchangeable with [ni kanye]
practiceQuestions.explanation: [Ere] is restricted to present tense usage in Dholuo.

practiceQuestions.question: If a sentence seeks the location of an object using [ere], how should it be structured?
options: The object should be placed at the beginning, followed by [ere]
[Ere] should be placed before the object
The object should follow [ni kanye]
The sentence should start with [ni kanye]
practiceQuestions.explanation: When using [ere] to ask about the location of an object, it should be placed before the object in the sentence.

practiceQuestions.question: What can be concluded about the choice between [ere] and [ni kanye]?
options: It is primarily based on strict syntactic rules
It is mostly arbitrary, with a few grammatical restrictions
It depends on whether the sentence is interrogative or declarative
It is determined by tense and aspect alone
practiceQuestions.explanation: The choice between [ere] and [ni kanye] is guided more by grammatical and semantic restrictions than rigid syntactic rules.

topics.title: Positioning of the Negative Element Ok

practiceQuestions.question: In Dholuo, where can the negative morpheme [ok] be positioned in a sentence?
options: Anywhere in the sentence
Only before the verb
Immediately before or after the sentence-initial constituent
At the end of the sentence
practiceQuestions.explanation: [Ok] is flexible but must appear immediately before or after the sentence-initial constituent.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following sentences correctly follows the positioning rules of [ok]?
options: Ng'at ni nyal ok ketho gira kamano
Ng'at ni nyal ketho gira kamano ok
Ng'at ni ok nyal ketho gira kamano
Ng'at ni nyal ketho ok gira kamano
practiceQuestions.explanation: The correct positioning of [ok] is after the sentence-initial alpha term but before the auxiliary verb.

practiceQuestions.question: What happens to 'ok' when there is no alpha term in the sentence?
options: It follows the verb
It appears before the verb in all cases
It appears after the subject
It becomes optional
practiceQuestions.explanation: Without an alpha term, [ok] appears directly before the verb to maintain grammaticality.

practiceQuestions.question: In predications without an alpha term, where must [ok] be placed?
options: Before the first noun
Before the verb
At the end of the sentence
After the verb
practiceQuestions.explanation: In the absence of an alpha term, [ok] must precede the verb.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following sentences demonstrates correct positioning of [ok] in a structure without an alpha term?
options: Okel ok ne japidi nanga
*Okel ne japidi nanga ok
*Okel ne ok japidi nanga
Ok okel ne japidi nanga
practiceQuestions.explanation: 'Ok okel ne japidi nanga' places [ok] correctly before the verb when no alpha term is present.

practiceQuestions.question: If a sentence contains an auxiliary verb like [bi(ro)] 'to come' as a future marker, how should [ok] be positioned?
options: Immediately before the auxiliary verb
Immediately after the auxiliary verb
At the end of the sentence
Between the auxiliary and the main verb
practiceQuestions.explanation: [Ok] should precede the auxiliary verb [bi(ro)] to correctly mark negation.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following sentences correctly places [ok] when the future auxiliary verb [bi(ro)] is present?
options: *Bi ok neg diel ne welo
Ok bi neg diel ne welo
*Diel bi ok neg ne welo
*Neg ok bi diel ne welo
practiceQuestions.explanation: 'Ok bi neg diel ne welo' shows the proper placement of [ok] before the auxiliary [bi].

practiceQuestions.question: How does the presence of a Time Adverb (TA) affect the placement of [ok]?
options: [Ok] must always come before the Time Adverb
[Ok] may come before or after the Time Adverb, depending on the sentence structure
[Ok] must always be at the end of the sentence
[Ok] cannot be used with a Time Adverb
practiceQuestions.explanation: [Ok] placement can vary relative to the Time Adverb depending on the sentence configuration.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following sentences correctly positions [ok] with respect to the Time Adverb (TA)?
options: Ok kawuono Otieno bi neno sinema
*Otieno ok kawuono bi neno sinema
*Otieno kawuono bi ok neno sinema
*Kawuono Otieno bi ok neno sinema
practiceQuestions.explanation: The sentence 'Ok kawuono Otieno bi neno sinema' correctly places [ok] before the TA and the subject.

practiceQuestions.question: What is the primary rule governing the placement of [ok] in Dholuo sentences?
options: [Ok] must always be at the beginning of the sentence
[Ok] must always follow a noun
[Ok] must be placed immediately before the verb in the absence of an alpha term
[Ok] can be placed anywhere as long as the meaning is clear
practiceQuestions.explanation: When there's no alpha term, [ok] must immediately precede the verb to function correctly.

cat.title: Dholuo Predicate Frames, Expression Rules and Complex Sentences Assessment
cat.description: This CAT evaluates knowledge of Dholuo predicate frames, expression rules, and complex sentence structures.

questions.question: [Predicate Frames] Which of the following best describes an intransitive predicate frame in Dholuo?
options: It requires a subject and a direct object.
It requires a subject, indirect object, and direct object.
It requires only a subject and no object.
It requires a subject and a locative complement.

questions.question: [Predicate Frames] Which verb category in Dholuo includes actions where the subject is the experiencer rather than the agent?
options: Unergative verbs
Ditransitive verbs
Unaccusative verbs
Monotransitive verbs

questions.question: [Predicate Frames] Which predicate frame is exemplified by the sentence "Omondi miyo nyar gi pesa"?
options: Intransitive
Monotransitive
Ditransitive
Reflexive

questions.question: [Predicate Frames] Which of the following is NOT considered a satellite in a Dholuo predicate frame?
options: Time
Location
Subject
Manner

questions.question: [Predicate Frames] Why does Functional Grammar (FG) reject traditional subject-object assignments in Dholuo?
options: Because Dholuo lacks a clear distinction between subjects and objects.
Because Dholuo relies more on semantic and pragmatic roles for sentence structure.
Because the Subj-Obj distinction only applies to passive voice constructions.
Because Dholuo allows free word order.

questions.question: [Predicate Frames] In unmarked Dholuo constituent order, what typically comes immediately after the verb?
options: The alpha term
The lowest-ranked term
The highest-ranked non-alpha function
The satellite

questions.question: [Predicate Frames] Which pragmatic function introduces a referent into discourse by framing its relevance?
options: Tail
Theme
Focus
Topic

questions.question: [Predicate Frames] Which sentence correctly demonstrates a Tail function in Dholuo?
options: Kwach inego.
Ok adware, wiye duong' no.
Juma e ma ji dwaro.
Nyako ma biro no en osiepni?

questions.question: [Predicate Frames] Which focus function in Dholuo is used to correct incorrect prior information?
options: Expanding Focus
Selective Focus
Replacing Focus
Parallel Focus

questions.question: [Predicate Frames] Which focus marker is commonly used in relative clauses?
options: e
ma
e ma
gi

questions.question: [Predicate Frames] Which of the following prepositional markers is used for beneficiary marking in Dholuo?
options: gi
mar
e
ne

questions.question: [Predicate Frames] What is the unique syntactic behavior of the directional preposition "yo" in Dholuo?
options: It allows preverbal positioning.
It cannot co-occur with other general prepositions.
It must always be marked by "ma."
It is optional in most cases.

questions.question: [Predicate Frames] Which of the following sentences best demonstrates a passive predicate frame?
options: Oneg diel.
Ng'ato nego diel.
Juma e ma ji dwaro.
Aketo chiemo e wi mesa.

questions.question: [Predicate Frames] Which of the following modifies a focus structure in Dholuo by introducing emphasis?
options: The addition of gi before the focus term
The use of e ma after the focus term
Placing the focus term after the verb
The omission of a subject pronoun

questions.question: [Expression Rules] Which of the following best describes the role of Expression Rules in Functional Grammar?
options: They determine semantic roles rather than word order.
They organize constituents based on preferential tendencies in sentence structure.
They ensure that all constituents appear in free order without restrictions.
They apply only to complex sentences and not simple ones.

questions.question: [Expression Rules] According to Dholuo Functional Patterning, where does the Alpha term (Agent) appear in a sentence?
options: Postverbal position (Ø)
Preverbal position (A)
Final position in the sentence
Between the verb and the object

questions.question: [Expression Rules] Which of the following correctly represents a V Go structure in Dholuo?
options: Juma ema kelo kong'o.
Japuonj omiyo nyathi buku.
Ng'ato tedo rech.
Nyathi dwaro ang'o?

questions.question: [Expression Rules] In which verb placement pattern does the Goal occur after a Recipient?
options: V Go
V Ben Go
V Rec Go
VØ

questions.question: [Expression Rules] Which of the following best explains why X-constituents (e.g., Beneficiary) can be postposed in Dholuo?
options: They are not semantically necessary in a sentence.
Dholuo permits movement of non-alpha terms without affecting grammaticality.
They always remain at the end of the sentence regardless of meaning.
The Beneficiary role is stronger than the Theme role.

questions.question: [Expression Rules] Which of the following is NOT an accurate description of word fronting in Dholuo interrogatives?
options: It places question words in preverbal positions.
It leads to paraphrase variations in question formation.
It allows alpha term interrogatives to appear postverbally.
It does not significantly alter the meaning of the question.

questions.question: [Expression Rules] Which of the following illustrates an interrogative structure where a non-alpha term is questioned?
options: Ng'a ma dwaro ruoth?
Ere wuon ot?
Nyathi dwaro ang'o?
Ng'a ma sibuor ochamo?

questions.question: [Expression Rules] Which of the following demonstrates a questioned focus construction in Dholuo?
options: Bende oyud jakuo?
Punda ng'a ma chamo?
Jakuo okawo ang'o?
Juma kelo kong'o.

questions.question: [Expression Rules] Which of the following best describes the difference between Straight Interrogatives and Questioned Focus Constructions?
options: Straight interrogatives use question words in their natural position, while Focus constructions highlight an element.
Focus constructions are always declarative, while straight interrogatives are not.
Straight interrogatives require auxiliary verbs, while Focus constructions do not.
There is no significant difference between the two.

questions.question: [Expression Rules] Which of the following illustrates a free or complementary distribution of an interrogative?
options: Ang'o ma jakuo okawo?
Sibuor ochamo ng'a?
Jakuo okawo ang'o?
All of the above

questions.question: [Expression Rules] Which of the following demonstrates a Focus-marked declarative construction in Dholuo?
options: Juma kelo kong'o.
Juma ema kelo kong'o.
Bende oyud jakuo?
Ng'a ma sibuor ochamo?

questions.question: [Expression Rules] Which of the following is grammatically incorrect according to Dholuo Functional Order?
options: Ng'ato omiyo Atieno pesa mathoth.
Jatedo otuono japidi chiemo.
Ere nyathi otieno?
Ang'o nyathi dwaro?

questions.question: [Complex Sentences] Which of the following sentences correctly demonstrates the flexibility of Time Adverb (TA) placement in Dholuo?
options: Otieno nyalo loso kom ne min kawuono.
Kawuono Otieno nyalo loso kom ne min.
Otieno kawuono nyalo loso kom ne min.
All of the above

questions.question: [Complex Sentences] In Dholuo, why can't a Time Adverb (TA) occur between the predicate and the binding constituent?
options: It disrupts the sentence's syntactic structure.
It changes the meaning of the sentence completely.
It results in an ambiguous focus structure.
Dholuo does not allow Time Adverbs in any sentence-final position.

questions.question: [Complex Sentences] Which of the following best explains the role of Cleft Constructions in Dholuo?
options: They provide additional satellite information.
They act as Focus markers by separating a unified phrase.
They introduce a syntactic pause in spoken discourse.
They are primarily used for negation.

questions.question: [Complex Sentences] Which of the following represents a proper cleft construction in Dholuo?
options: Rech ema nyathi dwaro.
Gi ma nyathi dwaro en rech.
Nyathi dwaro rech.
Otieno kawuono loso kom.

questions.question: [Complex Sentences] Which of the following differentiates a pseudo-cleft from a proper cleft in Dholuo?
options: Pseudo-clefts use relative clauses, while proper clefts do not.
Proper clefts contain more syntactic movement than pseudo-clefts.
Pseudo-clefts retain the object-verb order, while proper clefts alter it.
All of the above.

questions.question: [Complex Sentences] Why can't the word ere replace ni kanye in Dholuo focus constructions?
options: Ere only occurs in past-tense constructions.
Ere requires a pronominal subject to be grammatical.
Ere lacks the necessary syntactic flexibility in focus structures.
Ere must always be followed by an auxiliary verb.

questions.question: [Complex Sentences] Which of the following correctly demonstrates the required placement of ere in a question structure?
options: Ere-i?
I-ere?
Ere ni kanye?
Kanye ere?

questions.question: [Complex Sentences] In Dholuo negation, why must the negative morpheme "ok" follow the alpha term?
options: To preserve correct verb morphology.
To prevent ambiguity in focus assignment.
To ensure that the negative scope is correctly assigned.
All of the above.

questions.question: [Complex Sentences] Which of the following is grammatically incorrect in Dholuo negation?
options: Ok ng'at ni nyal ketho gira kamano.
Ng'at ni ok nyal ketho gira kamano.
Ng'at ni nyal ok ketho gira kamano.
Gira ok ng'at ni nyal ketho kamano.

questions.question: [Complex Sentences] When negating a sentence with an auxiliary verb, where must "ok" be placed?
options: Immediately before the auxiliary verb.
After the auxiliary verb but before the main verb.
After the main verb.
Anywhere in the sentence, as long as negation is intended.

questions.question: [Complex Sentences] Which of the following sentences correctly places "ok" in relation to an auxiliary verb?
options: Bi ok neg diel ne welo.
Ok bi neg diel ne welo.
Bi neg ok diel ne welo.
Neg ok bi diel ne welo.

questions.question: [Complex Sentences] Which of the following negated sentences correctly positions a Time Adverb (TA)?
options: Ok kawuono Otieno bi neno sinema.
Kawuono Otieno ok bi neno sinema.
Otieno bi neno sinema ok kawuono.

questions.question: [Complex Sentences] In Dholuo, which word order constraint applies when both a Time Adverb and "ok" appear in a sentence?

The Time Adverb can appear pre-initially, but "ok" must follow the alpha term.
